msDesc.head:
Letter from
Frances Edgeworth
to Mrs. Strickland, Lough Glyn, Castlerea Nov. 16. 1828 Stamp saying "EDGEWORTHSTOWN" and "52"

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworthâ€™s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

revisionDesc.change: Created file for letter, encoded letter

div.p:
On the 21st - or 22d of this month we shall
be very glad to see Mr Strickland We
who remain at home for Lovell I am sorry
to say - and he is sorry to think, will be
at Trim where he has long engaged to be.
I say Mr Strickland for I perceive dear
Mrs Strickland that you cannot leave
home at present with so many inva
-lids invalids - Your mind would be with
them and we should have no good of you
as people say in this country - and though
I do not love putting off, both Fanny and
I foresee that you will put off your coming
to some more convenient season, when you
can bring one or two of the girls - or boys
with you. Now I cannot must deny myself
the pleasure of saying come, to any of them
for I literally have but one bed to offer
Mrs Sneyd and her maid occupying two rooms
(a large & a small one) lessens the accommodations

for visitors and from our family very much
and of the three remaining bedrooms
the Mission Street friends occupy two.
This day is so fine that all your little
patients will be benefitted by it I hope
and your mind fully relieved from anxiety -
Miss Bartletts being ill is a de malheur
that I did not look to at all.

I am not surprised that you are anxious to hear
Mr Strickland speak in public and I hope earnestly
that his stomach will allow him to gratify you &
serve the public by giving them a little chapter of
good sense in plain intelligible language
I like very much the saying that he does not
speak too high English for the people to com
=prehend comprehend . Would to heaven that English
or Irish could make the world understand
that their true interest consists in very
different pursuits from political squabbles.
But society after a certain period must I suppose
come sometimes to a state of effervescence - its

its own fermentation will at last work itself clear -
Maria and Fanny tell me that nothing can
be settled about their going at present - and at
all counts we shall see Mr Strickland next week
when they may discuss the subject.
How very good it was of him to leave Stoker's
delight
-ful delightful journal here! - and now perhaps if you have
quite finished reading it you could lend us
Ward's Mexico - if Mr S. can bring it with
him. This has been a very favorable autumn
for the Gardens - and even Dahlias and Nasturtiums
were in high beauty till last
week when one nights frost
put an end to them at once - but the overblown
Roses on the trellis are in the most brilliant beauty
just now - quite as full of flowers as they
were last June.

I see by the last English paper that Mr Stafford
Cooke is tormenting the people of Stafford by
claiming their houses as his property - and has
got all that have settled by the title's having
awarded to the Jerningham family?

I hope you have got a groom that gives you
satisfaction - Though our servant appears honest & sober
& careful we have been very unlucky in our horses lately
and have been without the use of one of them for
the last fortnight - but I hope he may not die.
I should thank you for very many excellent Birds far

better than those we get in our bogs & Mountains
as they called. I was surprised to find in Brooks
that the feather's of the Ptarmigan - (a species of
Grouse) was one of the most valuable objects of traffic in
Lapland - Sixty thousand birds being shot in one
province annually! How are the numbers kept up?
My love to dear Cissy and Hal - & Kate - The Celsia
is in great beauty still - and the little Rose tree is in
flower -
div.closer:
Adieu dear Mrs Strickland always your
Sincerely affectionate
F Edgeworth

postscript.p:
Who is the Bishop of
Maronia Maroneia
?
